user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_to_uint64_n_:
```c
size_t
MHD_str_to_uint64_n_ (const char *str,
                      size_t maxlen,
                      uint64_t *out_val)
{
  uint64_t res;
  size_t i;

  if (! str || ! maxlen || ! out_val || ! isasciidigit (str[0]))
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  i = 0;
  do
  {
    const int digit = (unsigned char) str[i] - '0';

    if ( (res > (UINT64_MAX / 10)) ||
         ( (res == (UINT64_MAX / 10)) &&
           ((uint64_t) digit > (UINT64_MAX % 10)) ) )
      return 0;

    res *= 10;
    res += (unsigned int) digit;
    i++;
  } while ( (i < maxlen) &&
            isasciidigit (str[i]) );

  *out_val = res;
  return i;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
*out_val = res;
  return i;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: When str is non-null, maxlen > 0, out_val is non-null and str[0] is a digit (so the initial checks pass), and the loop terminates normally because either i reaches maxlen or the next character is not a digit (and no overflow return occurred), control reaches the assignment '*out_val = res;' and 'return i;'. Thus these statements are reachable (e.g. input "123" with sufficient maxlen), so there is no unreachable code in this fragment.
